thread.title: Jets fly out of the gate | Hockey | Sports Sun
thread.title_full: Jets fly out of the gate | Hockey | Sports | Toronto Sun

author: torontosun.com
title: Jets fly out of the gate | Hockey | Sports Sun
text:
Better than expected, yet ample room for improvement.
Those are my prevailing thoughts after watching the Winnipeg Jets win three of four games on the road to start a new season.
As is often the case at this point of a fresh campaign, there are issues to be sorted out for every team around the NHL and the Jets are no different.
When you earn road wins over the Boston Bruins, New Jersey Devils and New York Rangers and the lone loss comes against the New York Islanders, you won't hear a lot of complaints from either the Jets' players or members of the coaching staff – though they weren't blind to the warts either.
“We’ve just got to keep building,” said Jets captain Andrew Ladd. “In this league you take the points when you can get them.”
Ladd couldn't be more right.
In a league where points are so tough to come by and nearly triple digits are required just to qualify for the post-season, it's important for teams to put them in the piggy bank as frequently and early as possible.
The reason a 3-1 start could be considered somewhat surprising is simply that some growing pains are expected when a group integrates three rookie forwards into a lineup and features four guys up front who weren't NHL regulars last season.
Certainly the kids have been all right, with Nikolaj Ehlers making the biggest impact and Nic Petan and Andrew Copp working to earn more ice time on the fourth line.
The increase in skill has been evident with the Jets, while the high-risk plays haven't been plentiful.
The sample size is small, but while goaltending remains a hot topic, both Ondrej Pavelec and Michael Hutchinson have done their part – and then some.
“Our goalies have done a great job,” said Jets centre Bryan Little. “Something we can get better at is kind limiting teams chances against and trying to make sure that we're not giving up 40 shots a night for our goalies like we have been.”
Indeed, the Jets haven't been as sharp as they'd like to be in the defensive zone, but that should come with time.
Having above-average goaltending is critical for any team with designs on the playoffs and the Jets can't afford anything less.
While there's a long way to go, Pavelec has taken steps to show that perhaps last season's career bests in goals against average and save percentage might be the new normal.
Hutchinson, meanwhile, is playing with a lot of confidence and the early indications are that he's made some adjustments after fading a bit during the stretch run last spring.
Penalties were a concern in three of the four games and while several calls were marginal, the Jets can't afford to let discipline – or lack thereof – become a recurring theme.
Playing on the edge will lead to minors, but offensive-zone stick infractions must be kept to a minimum.
Spending nearly half a period playing shorthanded – like they did during the first period against the New York Islanders and second period against the Rangers – is bound to catch up with the Jets at some point.
On the flip side, the Jets penalty kill has been pretty sharp, killing off 14-of-17 chances so far and getting a shorthanded goal from Bryan Little on Tuesday that proved to be the game-winner.
“I really liked our penalty kill and it got better and I really liked our composure. That's the key piece to it,” said Jets head coach Paul Maurice, who bit his tongue and didn't criticize the officials. “(Playing) On back-to-back nights where we have a run of penalties, we didn't lose our focus. We got the kill and got stronger and then got a real nice payoff on it, for doing the right things.”
The Jets aren't about to let this strong start fool them, there's no time to put their collective feet on the desk and get fat reading their press clippings.
“We weren’t happy with (Monday's 4-2 loss to the Islanders) but it’s (about) how you respond,” said Jets defenceman Mark Stuart. “That’s a great way to respond. We can go home feeling good about that, but it’s a long road ahead.”
It most certainly is, but with six games on home ice upcoming, the Jets have already put themselves in a much better position than they did 12 months ago when they stumbled out of the gate with a 1-start and were searching for answers before committing to the style of play that eventually got them into the Stanley Cup tournament.
ken.wiebe@sunmedia.ca
Twitter.com/WiebeSunSports
Jets fly out of the gate Plenty of impressive things, still work to do
